chapters.6: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Thus the highest-priority functional group in MCAT-tested nomenclature, and all other groups are named as substituents using prefixes.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CA - Carboxylic acids. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A carbon double-bonded to an oxygen.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CG - carbonyl group. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In an amide, the hydroxyl group is replaced by an amino group (nitrogen-containing group).
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: AG - amino group. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Common Name Methanal Formaldehyde Ethanal Acetaldehyde Propanal Propionaldehyde Propanone Acetone Ketones and aldehydes both take precedence over both alcohols and hydrocarbon chains, and the functional group that is the highest priority determines the suffix.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: IN - IUPAC Name. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.term: International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The primary goal of the International Union of Pure and Applied Chemistry (IUPAC) naming system is to create an unambiguous relationship between the name and structure of a compound.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'inter' = between. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Atoms besides carbon and hydrogen, like oxygen, nitrogen, phosphorus, or halogens.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hetero' = different. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Nonhyphenated roots that are part of the name, however, are included; these are modifiers like iso–, neo–, or cyclo–.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Nonhyphenated, modifiers. Link these to 'cyclo'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The chain is numbered so that the carbon attached to the hydroxyl group (–OH) gets the lowest possible number—even when there is a multiple bond present.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Cyclic, which may result from the intramolecular dehydration of a dicarboxylic acid.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: result, intramolecular, dehydration. Link these to 'anhydrides'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Alkanes are hydrocarbons without any double or triple bonds.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Carboxylic acids are always terminal, although their derivatives may occur within a molecule.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Carboxylic, always, although. Link these to 'derivatives'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: IUPAC Name Common Name Methanal Formaldehyde Ethanal Acetaldehyde Propanal Propionaldehyde Propanone Acetone Ketones and aldehydes both take precedence over both alcohols and hydrocarbon chains, and the functional group that is the highest priority determines the suffix.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pro' = before/for. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: IUPAC Name Common Name Methanal Formaldehyde Ethanal Acetaldehyde Propanal Propionaldehyde Propanone Acetone Ketones and aldehydes both take precedence over both alcohols and hydrocarbon chains, and the functional group that is the highest priority determines the suffix.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pro' = before/for. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The MCAT does not explicitly test reactions of alkenes or alkynes, but you may still see the suffixes –ene and –yne, which signify double and triple bonds, respectively.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: explicitly, reactions, alkenes. Link these to 'alkenes'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: But you may still see the suffixes –ene and –yne, which signify double and triple bonds, respectively.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: suffixes, signify, double. Link these to 'alkynes'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Or hydrates, are not commonly seen because they spontaneously dehydrate (lose a water molecule) to produce carbonyl compounds with the functional group C=O.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Diols with hydroxyl groups on the same carbon are called geminal diols; diols with hydroxyl groups on adjacent carbons are called vicinal diols.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Name the straight-chain alkane to which the formula refers and draw one alternative.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: MF - Molecular Formula. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Meaning that they appear at the end of a parent chain, while ketones are found in the middle of carbon chains.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Meaning, appear, parent. Link these to 'chain-terminating'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Named by replacing the –e in the name of the parent alkane with the suffix –one.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: replacing, parent, alkane. Link these to 'Ketones'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Named similarly to esters, except that the suffix becomes –amide.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: similarly, except, suffix. Link these to 'amides'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: ____________; substituent prefix: ____________ Ketone suffix: ____________; substituent prefix: ____________ Fill in the common names in the following chart.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: substituent, Ketone, substituent. Link these to 'SUFFIX'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Aldehydes and ketones contain a carbonyl group—a carbon double-bonded to an oxygen.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Aldehydes, ketones, contain. Link these to 'carbonyl'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Aldehydes and ketones contain a carbonyl group—a carbon double-bonded to an oxygen.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Aldehydes, ketones, contain. Link these to 'group'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Esters use the suffix –oate or the prefix alkoxycarbonyl–.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Esters, suffix, prefix. Link these to 'alkoxycarbonyl'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Cis–trans isomers (formerly called geometric isomers) are a specific subtype of diastereomers in which substituents differ in their position around an immovable bond, such as a double bond, or around a ring structure, such as a cycloalkane in which the rotation of bonds is greatly restricted.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'tri' = three; 'geo' = earth. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Characteristics of processes that don’t change the composition of matter, such as melting point, boiling point, solubility, odor, color, and density.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pro' = before/for. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In which the molecule is visualized along a line extending through a carbon–carbon bond axis.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pro' = before/for. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Nonbonded strain is the dominant source of steric strain in the flagpole interactions of the cyclohexane boat conformation.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'inter' = between. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Unlike conformational isomers that interconvert by simple bond rotation, configurational isomers can only change from one form to another by breaking and reforming covalent bonds.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'iso' = equal. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Both enantiomers and diastereomers can also be considered optical isomers because the different spatial arrangement of groups in these molecules affects the rotation of plane-polarized light.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'iso' = equal. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Differ by rotation around a single (σ) bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'iso' = equal. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Isomers (formerly called geometric isomers) are a specific subtype of diastereomers in which substituents differ in their position around an immovable bond, such as a double bond, or around a ring structure, such as a cycloalkane in which the rotation of bonds is greatly restricted.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'trans' = across. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Cis–trans isomers (formerly called geometric isomers) are a specific subtype of diastereomers in which substituents differ in their position around an immovable bond, such as a double bond, or around a ring structure, such as a cycloalkane in which the rotation of bonds is greatly restricted.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'trans' = across. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Torsional strain, and nonbonded strain (sometimes referred to as steric strain).
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: AS - Angle strain. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: And nonbonded strain (sometimes referred to as steric strain).
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: TS - Torsional strain. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Dominant source of steric strain in the flagpole interactions of the cyclohexane boat conformation.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: NS - Nonbonded strain. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Nonbonded strain (van der Waals repulsion) results when nonadjacent atoms or groups compete for the same space.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: VDWR - van der Waals repulsion. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: This carbon will be an asymmetrical core of optical activity and is known as a chiral center.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CC - chiral center. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The rotation of this plane-polarized light by a chiral molecule.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: OA - Optical activity. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: When both (+) and (–) enantiomers are present in equal concentrations, they form a racemic mixture.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: RM - racemic mixture. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The relative configuration of a chiral molecule is its configuration in relation to another chiral molecule (often through chemical interconversion).
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: RC - relative configuration. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: On the other hand, the absolute conformation of a chiral molecule describes the exact spatial arrangement of these atoms or groups, independent of other molecules.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: AC - absolute conformation. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Priority is assigned based on the atom bonded to the double-bonded carbons: the higher the atomic number, the higher the priority.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pre' = before. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: With equal concentrations of two enantiomers, will not be optically active because the two enantiomers’ rotations cancel each other out.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: RM - Racemic mixtures. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Have four different groups attached to the central carbon.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CC - Chiral centers. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In which priority is given by looking at the atoms connected to the chiral carbon or double-bonded carbons; whichever has the highest atomic number gets highest priority.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pre' = before. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Like structural isomers—and all isomers, for that matter—stereoisomers have the same chemical formula.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'iso' = equal. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: An object is considered chiral if its mirror image cannot be superimposed on the original object; this implies that the molecule lacks an internal plane of symmetry.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: object, considered, chiral. Link these to 'chiral'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Two molecules that are nonsuperimposable mirror images of each other are called enantiomers.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'anti' = against. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: If the signs are different, a higher-energy (less stable) antibonding orbital is produced.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two; 'anti' = against. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Created by head-to-head or tail-to-tail overlap of atomic orbitals that have opposite signs and are energetically unfavorable.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two; 'anti' = against. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: If the signs of the wave functions are the same, a lower-energy (more stable) bonding orbital is produced.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Created by head-to-head or tail-to-tail overlap of atomic orbitals of the same sign and are energetically favorable.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Contain one σ bond and two π bonds.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'tri' = three. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Each orbital can hold two electrons, which are distinguished by the spin quantum number, ms.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: SQN - spin quantum number. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Obtained mathematically by adding or subtracting the wave functions of the atomic orbitals.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: MO - molecular orbitals. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Σ bonds, accommodating two electrons.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: SB - single bonds. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Shorter than a single bond, and a triple bond is shorter than a double bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: DB - double bond. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Formed by mixing different types of orbitals.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: HO - Hybrid orbitals. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Describe the size, shape, orientation, and number of atomic orbitals an element possesses.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: QN - Quantum numbers. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Quantum numbers describe the size, shape, orientation, and number of atomic orbitals an element possesses.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: AO - atomic orbitals. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Contain one σ bond and one pi (π) bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: DB - Double bonds. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: This apparent discrepancy is accounted for by the theory of orbital hybridization.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Conjugation requires alternating single and multiple bonds because this pattern aligns a number of unhybridized p-orbitals down the backbone of the molecule.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Conjugation, requires, alternating. Link these to 'Conjugation'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: L, which ranges from 0 to n – 1 for a given energy shell.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Spherical and symmetrical, centered around the nucleus.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: 2, the resulting bond is called a sigma (σ) bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: resulting, called. Link these to 'sigma'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Sigma (σ) bonds, which contain two electrons.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: N, corresponds to the energy level of a given electron in an atom and is essentially a measure of size.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: PQN - principal quantum number. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Ml, which ranges from –l to +l for a given subshell.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Or Ka, measures the strength of an acid in solution.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Perfect examples for demonstrating nucleophile–electrophile reactions.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving; 'sub' = under. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: (SN1) reactions contain two steps.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving; 'sub' = under. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: (SN2) reactions contain only one step, in which the nucleophile attacks the compound at the same time as the leaving group leaves.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving; 'sub' = under. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Defined as an electron donor in the formation of a covalent bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: When Lewis acids and bases interact, they form coordinate covalent bonds—covalent bonds in which both electrons in the bond came from the same starting atom (the Lewis base), as shown in Figure 4.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.definition: Thus, more acidic molecules will have a smaller (or even negative) pKa; more basic molecules will have a larger pKa.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: E4 - Equation 4.2. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Essentially the opposite of coordinate covalent bond formation: a bond is broken and both electrons are given to one of the two products.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hetero' = different. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Element or compound in an oxidation–reduction reaction that accepts an electron from another species.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Electron donors; they have a lone pair of electrons and are often anions.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Brønsted–Lowry acids are proton donors; Brønsted–Lowry bases are proton acceptors.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Defined as “electron-loving” species with a positive charge or positively polarized atom that accepts an electron pair when forming new bonds with a nucleophile.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Leaving groups are the molecular fragments that retain the electrons after heterolysis.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'lysis' = breaking down; 'hetero' = different. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Defined as an electron acceptor in the formation of a covalent bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: LA - Lewis acid. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A Lewis acid is defined as an electron acceptor in the formation of a covalent bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: EA - electron acceptor. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A Lewis base is defined as an electron donor in the formation of a covalent bond.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: ED - electron donor. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Molecular fragments that retain the electrons after heterolysis.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: LG - Leaving groups. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In SN2 reactions, the nucleophile actively displaces the leaving group in a backside attack.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: BA - backside attack. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In which the oxidation states of the reactants change.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: O(R - oxidation–reduction (redox) reactions. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: N indicator of the hypothetical charge that an atom would have if all bonds were completely ionic.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: OS - Oxidation state. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Electron acceptors; they have vacant orbitals or positively polarized atoms.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: LA - Lewis acids. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Proton donors; Brønsted–Lowry bases are proton acceptors.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: BA - Brønsted–Lowry acids. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Can act as either acids or bases, depending on reaction conditions.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: AM - Amphoteric molecules. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Some molecules, like water, have the ability to act as either Brønsted–Lowry acids or bases, making them amphoteric.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: ability, either, making. Link these to 'amphoteric'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Defined as “nucleus-loving” species with either lone pairs or π bonds that can form new bonds to electrophiles.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Ubiquinone is also called coenzyme Q and is a vital electron carrier associated with Complexes I, II, and III of the electron transport chain.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CQ - coenzyme Q. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Ing occurs when hydrogen atoms are attached to highly electronegative atoms like nitrogen, oxygen, or fluorine.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: When dissolved with dilute sulfuric acid in acetone, this is called the Jones oxidation, as shown in Figure 5.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: JO - Jones oxidation. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A mesylate is a compound containing the functional group –SO3CH3, derived from methanesulfonic acid; its anionic form is shown in Figure 5.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: MA - methanesulfonic acid. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Tosylates contain the functional group –SO3C6H4CH3, derived from toluenesulfonic acid.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: TA - toluenesulfonic acid. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Alcohols have the general formula ROH, with the functional group –OH referred to as a hydroxyl group.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: After reducing other functionalities in the molecule, the acetal or ketal can be reverted back to a carbonyl with aqueous acid, a step called deprotection.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'pro' = before/for. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Particularly acidic due to resonance within the phenol ring.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Particularly, acidic, resonance. Link these to 'phenols'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Compound containing the functional group –SO3CH3, derived from methanesulfonic acid; its anionic form is shown in Figure 5.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Compound, containing, functional. Link these to 'mesylate'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Contain the functional group –SO3C6H4CH3, derived from toluenesulfonic acid.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Contain, functional, derived. Link these to 'Tosylates'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Named by indicating the position of the carbonyls numerically and adding quinone to the name of the parent phenol.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: indicating, position, carbonyls. Link these to 'quinones'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: S are named by indicating the position of the carbonyls numerically and adding quinone to the name of the parent phenol.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: indicating, position, carbonyls. Link these to 'quinone'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: This molecule is also called phylloquinone and is important for photosynthesis and the carboxylation of some of the clotting factors in blood.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: molecule, called, phylloquinone. Link these to 'phylloquinone'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Contain the functional group –SO3CH3, which is derived from methanesulfonic acid.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Contain, functional, derived. Link these to 'Mesylates'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Ubiquinone is the most oxidized form that this molecule takes physiologically: it can also be reduced to ubiquinol upon the acceptance of electrons, as shown in Figure 5.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: These molecules can be further oxidized to form a class of molecules called hydroxyquinones.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: An aldehyde can be obtained from the partial oxidation of a primary alcohol, although only by pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC; C5H5NH[CrO3Cl]).
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two; 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: Weaker, anhydrous oxidizing agents like pyridinium chlorochromate (PCC) must be used for synthesizing aldehydes, or the reaction will continue oxidizing to the level of the carboxylic acid.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'di' = two; 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: Because nitrogen replaces the carbonyl oxygen, this is also an example of a nucleophilic substitution.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'phil' = loving; 'sub' = under. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: Because a small molecule is lost during the formation of a bond between two molecules, this is an example of a condensation reaction.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: CR - condensation reaction. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: When one equivalent of alcohol (the nucleophile in this reaction) is added to an aldehyde or ketone, the product is a hemiacetal or hemiketal, respectively, as shown in Figure 6.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'emia' = blood condition. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.chapter_title: Aldehydes and Ketones I: Electrophilicity and Oxidation–Reduction
flashcards.definition: Some common ammonia derivatives that react with aldehydes and ketones are hydroxylamine (H2N–OH), hydrazine (H2N–NH2), and semicarbazide (H2N–NH–C(O)NH2); these form oximes, hydrazones, and semicarbazones, respectively.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'hydro' = water. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.definition: Splitting patterns include doublets, triplets, and multiplets.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'tri' = three. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: GC, also known as vapor-phase chromatography (VPC), is similar to the other types of chromatography and is shown in Figure 12.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme; 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Uses a nonpolar card with a polar solvent.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme; 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: When the two solvents are mixed together, isobutyric acid will transfer to the water layer, which is called the aqueous phase (layer).
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The nonpolar ether layer is called the organic phase (layer).
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The process begins by placing the sample onto a solid medium called the stationary phase, or adsorbent.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Usually a liquid (or a gas in gas chromatography) through the stationary phase.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'ase' = enzyme. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A thin layer of silica gel or alumina adherent to an inert carrier sheet is used.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Extremely similar techniques, varying only in the medium used for the stationary phase.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Same as for thin-layer chromatography, although there are some differences.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The beads in the column are coated with charged substances so that they attract or bind compounds that have an opposite charge.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: The beads used in the column contain tiny pores of varying sizes.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: A protein of interest is bound by creating a column with high affinity for that protein.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: ) is another method that can be used for qualitative separation.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: ) was previously called high-pressure liquid chromatography.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Method for Separating Sample Ion-exchange The column is given a charge, which attracts molecules with the opposite charge.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In order to isolate these two phases, we use a piece of equipment called a separatory funnel, as shown in Figure 12.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: SF - separatory funnel. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: When TLC is performed, compounds are generally identified using the retardation factor (Rf), which is relatively constant for a particular compound in a given solvent.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: RF( - retardation factor (Rf. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Compounds with higher affinity for the stationary phase have smaller retardation factors and take longer to pass through, if at all; compounds with higher affinity for the mobile phase elute through more quickly.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: RF - retardation factors. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Separates vaporizable compounds according to how well they adhere to the adsorbent in the column.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Type of Column Chromatography Method for Separating Sample Ion-exchange The column is given a charge, which attracts molecules with the opposite charge.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: MFSS - Method for Separating Sample. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: In which the solvent is forced through the filter by a vacuum connected to the flask, is more often used when the solid is the desired product.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: VF - Vacuum filtration. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Mass spectrometry involves the ionization and fragmentation of compounds; these fragments are then run through a magnetic field, which separates them by mass-to-charge ratio.
flashcards.mnemonic: Acronym: MS - Mass spectrometry. Associate each letter with the word.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Based on the fundamental concept that like dissolves like.
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: fundamental, concept, dissolves. Link these to 'extraction'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Called the organic phase (layer).
flashcards.mnemonic: Key concepts: Called, organic. Link these to 'layer'.

flashcards.subject: Organic Chemistry
flashcards.definition: Nother tool that uses physical and chemical properties to separate and identify compounds from a complex mixture.
flashcards.mnemonic: Word roots: 'chrom' = color. Remember what these roots mean!
